utterances: We turn now to Kaj Larsen.
He's a former Navy SEAL who now works for Current TV.
He joins me now from Los Angeles.
Welcome to the show.
Thank you.
What can you tell me about how Navy SEALs train for this kind of rescue?
I can tell you that Navy SEALs are the premier special operations force, the premier maritime special operations force in the world.
As SEALs, we spend a lot of time training for what we call CQC or close quarters combat, and that simulates shipboard rescues and maritime rescues.
In addition, many SEALs in a SEAL platoon have been to sniper school.
And the incident you see now, they utilize U.S.
Navy SEAL snipers to achieve tactical resolution.
Why do you think it took five days before special ops could pull this off?
Well, I think the purpose here was to try and resolve this situation without resorting to violence.
And in a hostage scenario, any time there's a tactical engagement, the likelihood of having a casualty, including a hostage casualty, increases.
They're trying to avoid that at all costs, but a scenario presented itself where it became necessary to use lethal force.
From what you know about this situation, were there special circumstances to this rescue?
I mean, what sort of things would they have had to consider before starting it?
I think, tactically, what made this rescue so difficult was that the lifeboat was covered.
So they didn't - they couldn't - they didn't actually have eyes on the targets.
So that definitely caused the entire scenario to play out longer than it normally would in a hostage rescue scenario.
And from what you know of the extent of different operations Navy SEALs have to train for, did this seem like a particularly difficult operation to you?
This does seem like a difficult operation.
And, in fact, at any time that there are lives at stake, the situation is more intense and more dangerous.
But SEALs are trained very well to be adaptive and flexible to any kind of tactical environment that they're put in.
Kaj Larsen, paint a picture for us here of how this operation might look from the point of view of the rescuers.
Some are on another ship.
Are there frogmen in the water with guns?
How does that all look?
Well, it's a very good question.
And obviously, I'm not speaking for the Navy, but from what I understand, the snipers or the SEAL team was in an elevated position on the Bainbridge, shooting into the lifeboat.

And that is a very difficult tactical scenario not only because of the sea conditions, and their vision is partially obscured but that because in any scenario, when there's lead flying, there's the potential for something to go awry.
Luckily in this case, they were able to successfully execute the mission and to rescue the hostage without him being harmed.
So that's a good day for a frogman.
Kaj Larsen is a former Navy SEAL.
He now works for Current TV.
Thanks so much.
Thank you.
One of the key stops on Secretary Clinton's trip was the Egyptian resort city of Sharm El Sheikh.
The once-sleepy fishing village has a split personality today.
It's a sun-kissed playground for Western and Arab tourists, and a venue for conferences addressing some of the Middle East's thorniest problems.
The two Sharms co-exist but uneasily, as NPR's Peter Kenyon reports.

It may be hard to imagine looking at a coastline crammed with hotels, resorts and villas, but just a few decades ago, this was rock, sand and sea, with a scattering of tents pitched by fishermen who would rise before dawn to fish the pristine, blue waters of the Red Sea.
They weren't the only ones who saw the value of this point overlooking both the Gulf of Suez and the Straits of Tehran.
Israel conquered the area twice, in 1956 and '67, and during the Second Occupation, they built the first hotel at Naama Bay, now the heart of tourist Sharm.
(Soundbite of music)
After regaining control in 1982, the Egyptian government encouraged an explosion of development here and soon, the clubs were packed with Europeans and wealthy Arabs.
In a brief moment of foresight in 1983, the government created a national park, preserving some of the best coral reefs south of Naama Bay, protecting Sharm's reputation as a diving destination.
As another European jet lines up its approach above one of the numerous beachside restaurants and cafes that front Naama Bay, Alfonse Milad(ph) surveys the scene.
He sees alabaster-fleshed Russians and Europeans sprawled in their Speedos and bikinis.
He also sees the conservative, young Muslim men serving them beer, and he knows some of them will rush back from work to the newest mosque to pray for absolution.
Milad is a bit of a rarity, a longtime Sharm resident.
He first came here from Cairo 22 years ago and was so enchanted, he stayed.
Although he's looking at wall-to-wall development that stretches right around the bay, he can still picture Sharm as it was back then.
For me, it was a paradise, virgin land, very few people on the beach.
The sand is very clean.
Water is very clear.
It was much better than now, much, much.
Now, it's very crowded.
Perhaps not crowded enough for some, however.
With the global financial downturn spreading, hotel bookings are down, stays are shorter, and local businesses are laying off staff or giving them unpaid leave, waiting for things to pick up again.
Like most journalists, I mainly know the other Sharm El Sheikh, diplomatic Sharm, President Hosni Mubarak's favorite meeting site.
This is the sound of Mubarak welcoming delegates to the Gaza Donors' Conference.
(Speaking foreign language)
You'll have to take my word for that, as the host country is occasionally a bit too energetic in the translation department.
The Tower-of-Babel effect tickles the sense of humor of some of the scribes assigned to cover events here, which like many diplomatic summits, tend to feature overheated rhetoric and tepid results.
(Soundbite of surf)
Diplomatic Sharm, with its massive security, complicates life in tourist Sharm.

Those who do venture out of their all-inclusive resort compounds during summits find themselves waiting through endless police checkpoints, a reminder that Sharm was hit by terrorist attacks as recently as 2005.
But as long as the sun keeps shining, and the Middle East keeps having political problems, Sharm will have a future.
Peter Kenyon, NPR News, Sharm El Sheikh.
In a few minutes, we'll take a spin through the classics with a new twist, an Arab version of ""Richard III"" and ""12 Angry Men,"" Russian style.
In California, Governor Arnold Schwarzenegger is a good bet for re-election.
Just a year ago, his popularity tanked after he called a special election for initiatives voters despised.
Now most polls give Schwarzenegger a double-digit lead over his Democratic opponent, Phil Angelides.
NPR's Ina Jaffe reports.
Last year, after Schwarzenegger's whopping defeat, he did something that voters may wish politicians did more often: he apologized.
And in his State of the State Speech, he swore he'd learned his lesson.
Cool the rhetoric, find common ground, and fix the problems together.
So to my fellow Californians I say, message received.
(Soundbite of applause)
So the Republican governor spent much of this year working with the Democrats in the legislature on some bills at the top of their wish list.
With much public fanfare he's recently signed a groundbreaking measure to curb greenhouse gas emissions and a bill to lower prescription drug prices for the poor.
And at an inner city market in L.A., he put his autograph on a bill to raise the minimum wage to eight an hour.
Never mind that he previously vetoed two similar bills.
This will make a real difference to the lives of the hardest working people, if it's the homecare workers, the janitors, the farm laborers, and the list goes on and on and on.
At every one of these signing ceremonies, Schwarzenegger has been surrounded by and praised by prominent Democrats.
One of them, Speaker of the Assembly Fabian Nunez, is a campaign co-chair of the governor's Democratic opponent, Phil Angelides.
Nunez didn't see a conflict.
His progress is a Democratic agenda, and so our hope is that the voters of this state will follow our lead and elect a Democratic governor.
Though Nunez never actually mentioned that Democrat's name.
(Soundbite of crowd)
Phil.
Phil.
Phil.
Phil...
Phil Angelides has had a hard time finding an issue that Schwarzenegger hasn't gotten to first, so he's looked overseas.
At a union hall in Burbank, he told a crowd of supporters that when he's governor, he'll do whatever he can to bring California's National Guard home from Iraq.

When a shameful and phony war compromises the governor's ability to meet the needs of our people when a disaster strikes our state, then you better believe it's an issue in the race for the governor of the state of California.
Polls show nearly 80 percent of the state's Democrats want to bring at least some troops home from Iraq.
And Angelides still hasn't closed the deal with members of his own party.
Polls show just about 60 percent support him, which explains this ad tying Schwarzenegger to the politician Democrats hate the most.
(Soundbite of a political ad)
